awd_titl_txt: A Toolbox "Train the Trainer" Workshop for the C-Accel Program
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project, the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative (TDI) proposes to develop a "Train-the-Trainers" (T3) Program that will enable it to extend its successful Toolbox dialogue method, making it available to interested parties without requiring the extensive, face-to-face involvement of TDI. The centerpiece of the T3 Program will be a T3 workshop curriculum delivered at the first team leader meeting conducted by the U.S. National Science Foundation Convergence Accelerator (C Accel) Program. The TDI T3 Program will include three main elements: 1) an interactive 3-hour workshop designed to train team leaders to implement the dialogue-based Toolbox process for enhancing team communication and collaboration with their full teams, 2) didactic resources, such as videos and webinars, that support those interested in designing and facilitating Toolbox dialogue sessions, and 3) individualized and community mentoring that will provide ongoing support for teams in adapting these materials to meet their specific needs.

The T3 workshops will indirectly contribute to the broader impacts of the C-Accel Program as a whole. The C-Accel Program has the potential for broader impact in many domains, but this impact depends upon team members being able to identify and resolve differences in a transdisciplinary context along an accelerated timeline.

The TDI T3 workshop for C-Accel will advance knowledge along two fronts. First, it will provide C-Accel team leaders with the knowledge and skills to enhance the communicative and collaborative capacity of their teams.  Second, the TDI team will produce resources and provide consulting and mentorship designed to enhance the ability of C-Accel team leaders to deliver Toolbox workshops on their own.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The “A Toolbox ‘Train the Trainer’ Workshop for the C-Accel Program” project (hereafter, “the project”) was designed to support the NSF Convergence Accelerator Program during its first year. Directed by the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative (TDI) of Michigan State University, the project focused on enhancing the collaborative capacity of the teams in the first cohort of Convergence Accelerator awardees. The NSF Convergence Accelerator focuses on funding and facilitating complex, crossdisciplinary and cross-sector teams to conduct accelerated convergence research that addresses societal challenges of great consequence. Awardee cohorts are organized into thematically-focused tracks that interact during Phase 1 while moving quickly toward the development of convergent solutions to track-specific problems. Phase 1 Convergence Accelerator teams participate in an Innovation Curriculum designed to enhance their ability to conduct convergence research quickly, and this award enabled TDI to contribute to that curriculum.

 

In the project, TDI designed and delivered two “train-the-trainers” workshops during the curriculum session conducted by the Convergence Accelerator on 4 October 2019. One of these workshops was delivered to the awardees in Track A, Open Knowledge Network, and the other to awardees in Track B, AI and Future Jobs (B1) and the National Talent Ecosystem (B2). Prior to the workshops, the project team developed this new training model by drawing lessons from a previous TDI project, the NSF-funded EESE project, “Values and Policy in Interdisciplinary Environmental Science: A Dialogue-based Framework for Ethics Education” (SBE-1338614, SBE-1338626). The workshops were developed to achieve two goals:

 

  1. Introduce the awardees to the Toolbox dialogue method, an NSF-sponsored method for improving the ability of teammates from different disciplines and sectors to communicate with one another by enhancing their mutual understanding about unacknowledged similarities and differences, and
  2. Train them to use the Toolbox dialogue method with their full teams after the curriculum session ended.

 

During the three-hour workshops, participants were trained to identify fundamental differences in research worldview, articulate them in the form of prompts that can structure a dialogue revealing those differences, and then facilitate a brief dialogue using the prompts. Acquisition of these skills put them in a position to use the Toolbox dialogue method to enhance their team’s ability to communicate across differences in research worldview.

 

In addition, the project included funding to help TDI develop two instructional videos that are publicly available on YouTube: “What is the Toolbox Dialogue Initiative?” (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-qHFGXglnNg) and “Understanding the Toolbox Instrument” (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IjEzzYhCnAE). Finally, the project team worked with a software engineer to upgrade the Toolbox web application, used to support engagement with the dialogue prompts during a Toolbox workshop.

 

The project advanced scientific knowledge in three ways. First, it expanded the awareness Convergence Accelerator awardees in Tracks A and B have of the importance of collaborative process in the conduct of accelerated convergence research. Second, it provided TDI with the opportunity to take the Toolbox dialogue method, a workshop-based method that enhances communication and collaboration in crossdisciplinary research projects, and develop a systematic training approach that makes it more broadly available to complex research teams. Third, it enabled TDI with support needed to produce two publicly available instructional videos that introduce people to the Toolbox dialogue method and how it addresses communication challenges for crossdisciplinary research teams.

 

The project also had a number of broader impacts. First, by focusing on the facilitation of process, it helped the Convergence Accelerator projects in Tracks A and B pursue their broader impacts. Second, it provided the leaders of teams in Tracks A and B with knowledge about crossdisciplinary process, as well as facility with a method they could use to enhance the capacity of their teams to collaborate successfully. Third, it helped TDI expand its infrastructure and develop its method, which helped it contribute to subsequent tracks in the Convergence Accelerator and many other projects nationally and internationally. Finally, the project provided professional development for members of TDI, especially the post-doctoral researchers who contributed to the effort.
